title-group.article-title: Coordinates and Connections: Self, Language, and World in Edward Abbey and William Least Heat-Moon

Melville puts it, 'Isolatoes,' 'fleeing from all havens astern"' (559-60)
Melville
fleeing from all havens astern 559 Isolatoes

Thoreau's excited response to "Matter, vast, terrific" in what eventually appeared as The Maine Woods: "The Main Woods What is this Titan that has possession of me? Talk of mysteries!-Think of our life in nature,-daily to be shown matter, to come in contact with it,-rocks, trees, wind on our cheeks! the solid earth! the actual world! the common sense! Contact! Contact! Who are we? where are we?" (646)
Thoreau
646 Matter, vast, terrific
Desert Solitaire (1966-68)Desert Solitaire 1966
The Background of EcologyThe Background of Ecology

Lindeman "described the basic process of trophic dynamics as the transfer of energy in the ecosystem," arguing that "it simply was not possible to dis- tinguish the living from the nonliving parts of the ecosystem" (196)

E. P. Odum, author of the influential 1953 textbook Fundamentals of Ecology (with a second edi- tion in 1959 and a third in 1971), "turned to the problems of measuring flows of energy or matter in ecosystems and developing a theoretical framework to integrate the resultant mass of data" (199)
Odum
199 Fundamentals of Ecology
American Zoologist titled "Energy Flow in Ecosystems: A Historical ReviewEnergy Flow in Ecosystems: A Historical Review American Zoologist titled
McIntosh 200 200
McIntosh 193-241. 193

Abbey's distinction runs on for several pages, but it can be summarized in one of a series of epigrams that he offers: "Civilization is the vital force in human history; culture is that inert mass of institutions and organizations which accumulate around and tend to drag down the advance of life" (246).

Buell's view in The Environmental Imagination can serve to epitomize the prevailing consensus: "Thoreau is often thought of as Emerson's earthy opposite. But it would be truer to imagine him as moving gradually, partially, and self-conflictedly beyond the pro- gram Emerson outlined in Nature, which sacralized nature as humankind's mystic coun- terpart .... Thoreau became increasingly interested in defining nature's structure, both spiritual and material, for its own sake, as against how nature might subserve humanity, which was Emerson's primary consideration" (117)
